content: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: You could hardly blame Obama for the stimulus money. It is certainly worth the risk. Once the economy gets back on its feet, revenues will return and therefore bring down expected deficits. Further, the democrats have had a better record on debt....at least they do over the last 40 years or so. I will give Obama an opportunity to deal with the real issue (medicare) that will blow all records so if not dealt with. I agree that they do have a much better record on debt. My opinion on that is that government never, ever wants to stop expanding. And, it definitely doesn't want to get smaller. That is the basic flaw of government regardless of left or right ideologies. While Republicans like to cut taxes, they can never do so and keep a balanced check book due to this fact. Republican Congresses typically do spend far less (about half) than Democrats. But, their tax cuts far outweigh the slowdown in government growth. Democrat Congresses spend a lot of money and increase the size and scope of government. But, they work with the flow of the system. Instead of trying to slow down the growth, they create an equilibrium through the use of taxation. While this taxation doesn't always apply to everybody in the form of income (it usually goes disproportionately to the rich, much like Republican tax cuts), it does get everybody when Federal mandates roll down to the states who cannot keep up with current tide. A good example where we will see this in the near future (next 2-4 years) will be state unemployment. It is Federally mandated, state run (for the most part). The new mandates in accordance with the last stimulus bill will increase the size of UI programs on the state level. For two years that increase will be federally subsidized. But, in the future, employers will have to pay more taxes on UI to maintain the size of UI (remember, government never shrinks). This in turn will cause higher prices in service and goods. Or, in some cases, lower wages. Another good example of higher taxes on things other than income is inflation. Inflation is generally much higher in Democratically controlled Congresses due to the need to have more money in circulation to account for larger government. The general public is usually the last to get their hands on any new money, so while others higher up got to use the money while it was worth more, those of us in the general population get that money when it has depreciated in value. I would call that a tax. The economy will no doubt get back on its feet. But, the playing field has changed. We will be hamstringed with the cost of that stimulus. Artificial stimulus has never worked to fix the problem for the common people. It always is tilted more in the direction of helping special interests. And, it isn't a real market. It is the government trying to pick up the slack for the real market that doesn't want to spend. Look at the crash of 1920/1921 and look at what President Harding did. He did absolutely nothing to interfere with what the market wanted to do. Same goes for Reagan. They let the businesses fail and liquidate. Others stepped up to the plate to take the reins. They saw opportunity just as many smaller companies today would have saw great opportunities if the banks today failed. This stepping up to the plate fills the void and usually causes great growth as it did in both cases (1921 with the Roaring 20's and 1981 with the Reagan Revolution). Both of these points in time marked periods of some of the greatest growth in our history. And, as I have said, the thing that they both have in common is the allowing of failing companies to fail so that good companies can succeed. That is how a free market was designed and it does work. It is just that we instead listen to the people who are proven wrong the majority of the time.
quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: You could hardly blame Obama for the stimulus money. It is certainly worth the risk. Once the economy gets back on its feet, revenues will return and therefore bring down expected deficits. Further, the democrats have had a better record on debt....at least they do over the last 40 years or so. I will give Obama an opportunity to deal with the real issue (medicare) that will blow all records so if not dealt with.

Or, in some cases, lower wages. Another good example of higher taxes on things other than income is inflation. Artificial stimulus has never worked to fix the problem for the common people. It always is tilted more in the direction of helping special interests. And, it isn't a real market. It is the government trying to pick up the slack for the real market that doesn't want to spend. Look at the crash of 1920/1921 and look at what President Harding did. Both of these points in time marked periods of some of the greatest growth in our history. And, as I have said, the thing that they both have in common is the allowing of failing companies to fail so that good companies can succeed. That is how a free market was designed and it does work. It is just that we instead listen to the people who are proven wrong the majority of the time.

content: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: So the massive tax cuts to the rich were a good idea during war and natural calamity? What "massive" tax cut are you referring to? The drop from 39% to 36% for income tax? That's hardly "massive". Or are you referring to a drop in capital gains taxes? Oh, yeah, encouraging people to invest in businesses is just a terrible concept. We need to nip that s**t in the bud. Yeah, we need to teach those fatcats a lesson, and make them pay their "fair" share. Having the % of taxes paid by wealthy people steadily increasing while the tax burden on middle and low income payers steadily decreasing isn't "fair" enough. Let's soak 'em. Teach those rich ba****ds a lesson for saving money and investing or starting a small business or spending 8 years in school and getting a 6-figure job. We must stop the madness!
